author: misilva73
content: This is a good point. Ideally we would like to keep it consistent with other account access patterns. But this seems to be a specific problem here because we cannot charge the right amount of gas before actually loading the account. For other other access patterns, this does not happen, right?

author: misilva73
content:
We have two options: 
1. Only load the account if there is at least `COLD_ACCOUNT_COST_CODE` available. That way we prevent DOS attacks and make sure the address is only in the BAL if it is actually accessed
2. We check if the user can pay for `COLD_ACCOUNT_COST_NOCODE` before loading the account. If after loading, the account has code and the suer does not enough gas, we stop execution, charge the max available and still assume the accoutn was accessed (i.e., it goes in the BAL and in the warm addresses). This is not as good for DOS, but maybe better for users as reverts are more predictable

author: misilva73
content: I am leaning towards option 1, but would like to see <@316280621783580673> opinion

author: gurukamath
content: Yes. Option 1 is in my opinion a much simpler design in addition to being better on DOS. The one minor downside though is that ETH transfers to EOAs will now have to send at least 8100 gas to succeed which is not ideal (even though they are charged only 6000 gas)

author: gurukamath
content:
Another point that I came across is that there seems to be a bit of a circular dependency in the EIP when it comes to zero value transfers.

According to this [table](https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/blob/fb847de2fa6ae290c6a9ae078b2f4e5d39cce110/EIPS/eip-2780.md?plain=1#L268), zero value transfers to an EOA do not charge any access gas while zero value transfer to a contract charges `COLD_ACCOUNT_COST_CODE`. But we cannot tell whether an account is an EOA or contract without accessing it.
I think zero value transfers to an EOA should be charged at  `COLD_ACCOUNT_COST_NOCODE` for cold access
